1. Reference is made to your letter No. 1693/DSDT-DA1 dated 13 October 2022
requesting for our comments on the CP03 Contractor's pre-condition of an additional
advance payment (AAP) in the amount of 20% of the Accepted Contract Price
(approximately $46 million) and confirmation on financing the AAP through ADB loans. As
discussed during the joint review mission from 3 to 7 October 2022 and in the meeting with
Ha Noi People's Committee (HPC) on 13 October 2022, we understand that both HPC and
Ha Noi Metropolitan Railway Management Board (MRB) have in-principle agreed to the
AAP subject to a successful negotiation with the Contractor on all its pre-conditions for
works resumption including this AAP.

2. In general, ADB has no objection to proceed an AAP and finance it by the above
loans subject to sufficient substantiations/justifications by MRB, noting that an AAP is in
line with conditions of the signed CPO3 contract.‘ We suggest parties to have clear
agreement on the implementation schedule for the remaining works, time for completion
and responsibilities of both parties after the works resume. If there are obligations from
MBB to provide clearances for some actions of the Contractor, it should be stated clearly
how long such clearances would take. Besides, MRB may consider such AAP in instalments.

Based on the the Engineer’s certification of IPC no.36 (letter ret [b], on 05 December 2022 UJV submitted its invoices
requesting payment for full amount certified by the Engineer (letter ref [c]). In accordance with the Sub-Clause 14.7
[Payment] of the General Conditions of Contract, the Employer shall pay to the Contractor those amount within the
contractual timeframe.

However, concerning financing of the project, as the year of 2022 is coming to an end, the DGT loan agreement is going
to be expired. UJV is not aware of the DGT loan would be extended beyond 2022 or not. UJV has no visibility how the

letter ret [c] by remaining AFD's fund and the rest by DGT’s fund.

Failing to comply with Sub-Clause 14.7 by the Employer to pay UJV the amount requested in letter ref [c], UJV reserves
its right under the contract and/or at law to suspend the work or reduce the rate of work.

Despite HGU’s efforts and coordination with MRB, the deadline of 25% October 2017 indicated in the
letter ref. No. 1062/DSDT-BQLDA| dated 14" August 2017, which amended the deadline of 25* July
2017 in the Memorandum of Understanding (“MoU”) dated 25" January 2017, has arrived but no
Contract Amendment was signed.

Needless to say, HGU has fully committed to its obligation under the MoU to finalize and execute the
Contract Amendment including but not limited to agreeing the amount of cost compensation and has
requested for MRB's attention several times to settle the pending issues in relation to the Contract
Amendment amicably as shown in letters ref. No. HGU-MLT-00299-17-E dated 10° October 2017,
HGU-MLT-000312-17-E dated 16th October 2017 and HGU-MLT-00331-17-E dated 23” October
2017. But to this date HGU has not received any positive reply from MRB.

HGU reminds you that it has been in full cooperation with MRB. To illustrate, HGU has agreed to
MRB's proposal to change the precondition for Commencement Date from ‘Full Site Hand Over’ to
“Partial Site Hand Over’ for the sake of collaboration subject to the signing of the Contract
Amendment. However, HGU still suffers from MRB'’s continuing failure to grant access to and
possession of the parts of the Site pursuant to the agreed schedule in the MoU. Further, the parts of the
Site have not been cleared of obstacles though they were handed over. Nonetheless, we are struggling
to find out the way to proceed with construction work where areas are available. With this concem,
HGU notes that it has been suffering from additional delays and costs and they will be included in the
claims amount in future.

In the recent meeting on 19* October 2017 between the representatives of MRB and HGU, MRB
accepted that there has been its delay in executing Contract Amendment and that the Site hand over
and removal of public utilities remain unsolved. HGU particularly records that MRB stated that an
additional time is required to reach to the signing stage of the Contract Amendment at the meeting.

Taking all of the above circumstances into account, it is unquestionable that HGU is expressly entitled
to immediately exercise its rights under Sub-Clause 2.6 of the MoU at its sole discretion. However,
HGU still hopes to finalize this matter within this year. In this regard, without prejudice to any of
HGU’s rights under the Contract, MoU, or at law, MRB is requested to propose a satisfactory solution
as earliest as possible to conclude this matter by the end of the year 2017.

Dear Sirs, .
In response to the letter ref.[a], UJV would like to reply to the following.

UJV would like to correct PIC’s statements from the above-captioned letter ref. [a]: °....nolified thal additional time and
costs might incur as the ECO cables at viaduct S2-S3 was damaged by the CP02's cable tray’ and “Also, it is not
comprehensible that how CP02's cable tray could damage the ECO cables”. As per our notice of event ref.[b], the
damage of ECO cable S2-S3 was not caused by the CP02 cable tray itself but by the installation process of CP02 cable
tray cover. Therefore, the responsibility of protection lies on CP02 while they were installing cable tray cover. However,
such protection (applying rubber gasket to the edges of the CP02 cover) was never provided on the CP02 cable tray
cover by CP02.

Though the impact Is limited, UJV reserves its rights under the contract to claim for any further impacts may occur
due to this delay event.

Subject: Contract Package No 06: CP06's warranty period
UJV Letter Reference No; UJV-MLT-00314-23-E-UJV
Reference to 3 a. PIC-MLT-01718-18-E, received 10/05/2018

b. 1444/DSDT-DA1, received 05/08/2018
c. PIC-MOM-05803-21-E, dated 10/12/2021
d. PIC-MLT-01827-23-E-UJV, dated 26/04/2023

According to UJV's Baseline Work Programme approved by MRB/PIC (letter ref [a] and [b)), following the su bat
completion of Test Run, the Taking Over Certificate (TOC) shall be granted to UJV on the date of 15" September 2021. “ ot
The 2 years warranty will start right after the TOC which was supposed to take place from 16/09/2021 until 16/09/2023.
Therefore, by defauit, all UJV's equipment warranty will be explzed by 15/09/2023 as all the back to back agreement
between UJV and its suppliers will expire on the 15/09/2023. Furthermore, due to the delay of the Project, UJV fs not
able to enter this phase of warranty.

Besides, UJV also refers to the EoT1 granted by MRB/PIC until 31/12/2022 (referenced MoM [c)) and the Engineer's
assessment of UJV's EoT2 Interim Claim 1 & 2 whereby the Engineer advised an extension of Time for Completion
until 31/12/2023 (referenced letter [d]). The delay of the project is beyond UJV's control and therefore UJV is entitled
to EoT until the TOC is granted to UJV. Accordingly, the warranty period would be extended as well.

As all the warranty agreement with UJV suppliers will expire from the 15" of September 2023, UJV is not in a position
to systematically get further support from its suppliers. On case by case, UJV will seek from its suppliers to extend
warranty of its equipment and the associated costs of these extensions will be claimed in the EoT2 cost.

For all the non-extended warranties, UJV propose that during the warranty period of 2 years, the damage parts will be
replaced using the Customer spares and all the replacement or repair costs of these spares will be bom by the
Customer.
UJV trusts the above is in order.

In response to PIC letter referenced [a], UJV would like to remind the following.

With regards to interface management, as a general comment, by referring only to the Employer's Requirements and
omiting the Submitted Bid and Clarifications (in particular Vol 2, Answer to Clarifications requests PMP Item #6, and
IMP Item #4), which take precedence over the Employer's Requirements, the Engineer always serves a partial and
biased view of the Contractual obligations of the Parties. In terms of interface management, UJV is contractually bound
to the extent provided for in CP06 Contract in its entirety. "The Engineer is overall manager of the interface across the
Project” (as per letter ref. PIC-MLT-03038-16-E).

With regards to the subject matter, UJV would like to remind that EVN indicated during the meeting held on 26 April
2018 with MRB and UJV that the 2 power sub-stations foreseen in the Technical Design could not provide the
necessary power required in the Technical Design. The potential impact of the uncertainty on the EVN grid connections
was raised by UJV through letter ref. [f] dated 18 May 2018 and fed UV to put on hold related activities (purchasing of
MV cables and equipment, etc) and submit a notice of delay and compensation claim in June 2018 as no confirmation
on the power connection to EVN network had been received by 31 May 2018 (ref. [e)).

We refer to your above-mentioned letter [a] requesting the Contractor to provide “evidence (...) supporting documentation
about the background, degrees, qualifications, profeesional experience and skills of the candidate” proposed by UJV in its
letter of 13® September 2021 to act as Dispute Board (DB) member on this Project.

We are rather surprised by your late request for more information three weeks after UJV sent you Mr. Leloup's CV via our
letter above referenced (b).

Neither the provisions of Clause 45 paragraph 2 (a) of Decree No. 37/2015/ND-CP that MRB refers to, nor the provisions
of the Contract, require the Contractor to provide documents evidencing the qualifications, expertise and experience of
the proposed DB member and certainly not the extensive documentation that you wrongly consider to be “missing”,
namely: "(...) University Degrees. - Employment records. - Recommendation letters and other references of previous
Employers, current Employers, Clients and related Entities. - Certificates of membership and registration in professional
associations and institutions. - Certificates of registration of the Social Security System or similar. - Certificates of working
Ife of the Social Security System or similar. - Certificates of the master, course seminars and any other relevant similar
training courses taken by the candidate. - Recent project history. - Additional supporting evikience of the candidate
professional skills and capabilities, such as professional articles, publications and reports of the candidate in joumals and
other relevant means of communication, courses and seminars, evidences of claims resolutions and arbitrations that they
have provided and any others evidences (...)".

Further, UJV struggies to understand how proof of affiliation to a Security Social system have anything to do with the
“qualifications”, “expertise”, “experience” and “understanding” of a DB member.

to 25" October 2017 as per MRB's proposal is near to expire but so far, despite our efforts, we haven't yet
finalized such process. Up to now, the Contractor have continuously followed the Employer's instruction
and submitted revised Cost Analysis document setting out a proposal for the necessary amendments to the
Contract on 25" September 2017. However, with our regret, we have not received any official response
from the Employer.

please be informed that the actual situation adversely affected the performance of the Contract due to fails of

any entitlement and for any necessary actions on this matter.

mutual benefit of both parties in full respect of the spirit of the MoU.

omiting the Submitted Bid and Clarifications (in particular Vol 2, Answer to Clarifications requests PMP Item #6, and

was raised by UJV through letter ref. [f] dated 18 May 2018 and fed UV to put on hold related activities (purchasing of

removal and relocation of obstacles at S9 such as electric lines, telecommunication lines, traffic
signals, lighting poles, etc. This was recorded in the Site Handover minutes):

“The initial utility relocation, diversion and protection for the working site shall be completed

3. MRB did not carry out the above stated works but belatedly, 3 months after handover,

Progress.

2017; however, some trees still remain on that site. The car repair shop was finally removed in
June 2018.

the plan were not properly handed over to HGU to allow the Works to proceed, in accordance
with the Minutes of Site handover signed on 15/04/2017.

works on critical power supply works. We note that no reply has been received by 25 December 2020 and therefore,
as explained In our letter ref. [a], we proceed with these additional works in order not to further delay power supply

drainage system for a safe installation of cables. UJV therefore hereby gives notice under Clause 8.4 [Extension of

In response to PIC letter referenced [a], UJV wouid like to clarify the following.

As indicated in the letters ref.[e] and the Final Ciaim ref.[b], the delay event giving rise to the claim ls the late
confirmation of power connection to EVN network. Following UJV request on 18 May 2018 (ref.[fl) to receive clear
direction from PIC on the way forward after the meeting held with EVN, MRB, PIC and UJV on 26 April 2018, UJV
was expecting to receive a confirmation from PIC in due time, in accordance with Engineer's Duties as per PCC 3.1
(d).

However, final confirmation from PIC to UJV request was only received on 28 August 2018 through letter [c]. While
MRB letter (d] received 29 June 2016 clarified the location of EVN connection points in line with technical design, it
also confismed the power capacity issue with a tentative capacity provided by My Dinh and Cau Dien (27 MVA)
significantly lower than the technical design (37 MVA). As the riek on the power architecture associated with the
capacity Issue was acknowledged by PIC in letter referenced [e] but no direction was provided in response to UJV
request, UJV as @ prudent contractor has mitigated the risk of major rework and therefore extra costs for the project by
freezing related activities.

Subject: Contract Package No 06: The Engineer's Suspension of its Duties and Authority
— Response to MRB’s rejection of the Contractor's request for meeting
UJV Letter ReferenceNo:; UJV-MLT-00270-23-F-UJV

Reference to Letter No/ Date: a. UJV-MLT-00257-23-B-UJV, dated 25/05/2003
b, UJV-MLT-00232-23-B-UJV, dated 09/05/2023 Ey

UJV refers to its referenced letter [a] whereby UJV called for a meeting with MRB General Director regarding the
Engineer's suspension of its Duties and Authority assigned to him under the Contract. Indeed, as per UJV letter’s ref [a],
the meeting was planned to take place on the 31% of May 2023. However, MRB waited until just a day before the planned
meeting time to give Its excuse to postpone this meeting (please refer to attachment for detail). UJV would like to respond
as follows:

The reason why UJV called for this meeting is because MRB does not respond to the UJV's request for having the
Employer's advice immediately on the way forward since there is no Engineer on the project (UJV's letter ref [b]). The
purpose of the meeting as mentioned in UJV's letter ref [a] is to find solutions to mitigate the impact of the Engineer's
shutdown on the progress of CP06's package but not just limited to the MRB’s comments on EoT2 and CR/VR topic.
Indeed, since the Engineer caased its Duties and Authority, UJV has sent to MRB all documents, which are supposed to
be reviewed by the Engineer, for MRB's assessment In lieu of the Engineer. However, until the date of this letter, more
than one month has passed, UJV has not received any feedback from MRB and has no visibility at all on how MRB will
manage the project during the absence of the Engineer services. This has caused further delay in the progress of UJV's
Works, for which UJV Is not responsible for and will seek compensation.

Last but not least, UJV also would like to remind the Employer that, as defined in the Contract, it Is the Contractor's right
to call for a meeting any time to which the other shall attend to discuss arrangements for future work.

Therefore, to be compliant with the local regulations, the Contractor will pay the corresponding CIT
amount In the coming days. According to Section IV.3(a) of the Minutes of Contract Negotiation dated 21
April 2016, the Employer shall refund the CIT paid by the Contractor for the certified value of works. As
the money related to the IPA N°47 and N°48 was certified by the Engineer in letters (d) and (e), the
Employer is responsible for refunding the CIT of the Contractor relating to the above money.

on due time. Financial interests for late payment as defined in the Contract, refer to clause 14.8 of the

power line of Overhead crane in building 8 (reply to PIC letter No. PIC-MLT-
04086-21-E)
JV Letter Reference No; = UJV-MILT-00929-21-E-ADE

Reference to Letter No/ Date: a. PIC-MILT-04088-21-E received 13/09/2021
b. UJV-MLT-00893-21-E dated 30/06/2021

Dear Sirs,
In response to the Engineer letter ref. [a], UJV would like to reply with the following.

e With regards to PIC's requirement to provide the causal link between the wall opening and the damage on
powerline of the overhead crane, UJV reiterates that the root cause, which was already stated in the email se
to CP05 and PIC on 9 June 2021, Is “The cover of the wall opening of building 8, gridline F-G, is not fixed
correctly and has just damaged the power line of the overhead crane”. However, as per GCC 20.1: ‘the
Contractor shail give notice fo the Engineer, describing the event or circumstance giving rise to the claim”, the
Contract does not requrie to “demonstrate the impact of such event on your activities/works by addressing
rationale and presenting evidences” in the notice letter. It is indeed to be provided through the submission
of UJV's Claim.

e UJV confirms that there is no considerable damage to the power line of the overhead crane. However, UJV did
spend one day with additional manpower (1 supervisor, 1 technician, 1 operator) and machinery (1 scissor lif)
to restore the powerline.
Based on the above, UJV reserves its rights under the contract to claim for any impact related to this site event.

Dear Sirs,
In response to above referenced letter [a] from PIC, UJV would like to remind the following.

As a general comment, by referring only to the Employer's Requirements and omiting the Submitted Bid and
Clarifications (in particular Vol 2, Answer to Clarifications requests PMP item #6, and IMP Item #4), which take
precedence over the Employer's Requirements, the Engineer always serves a partial and biased view of the Contractual
obligations of the Parties. in terms of interface management, UJV is contractually bound to the extent provided for in
CPO06 Contract In its entirety.

The iseue raised by UJV in letter [c] did relate strictly to the interface management process since CP01 considered that
the ICD process was not adapted for Construction Drawings already approved by PIC/MRB and refused to provide input
data to CP06 through the ICDs opened since January 2018. The issue was contentious since CPO1 did not agree to
apply the ICD process imposed by PIC for all input data transmission.

UJV can not be blamed in any manner for escalating this type of issue to PIC/MRB as UJV has the obligation to report to
PIC for all interface management matters (especially if there ts an lesue), the Engineer being in charge of the
management of interfaces at the Project level, and as such acting as the adjudicator of any contentious issue.

Subject: CP03— Engineer's Instruction — Validity of Performance Security
(Response to PIC letter ref. PIC-MLT-00060-22-E received on 6" January 2022)

Reference: (i) PIC-MLT-00060-22-E
Dear Sirs,

The Contractor disagrees with your interpretation of the Contract with regard to the conditions of
extension of the Performance Security under Sub-Clause 4.2 of the General Conditions of Contract
(GCC). This Sub-Clause simply stipulates that the Contractor is obliged to take action to extend the PS
only after 18* December 2021, which we have agreed to do, and which you confirmed your
understanding of in your last letter (Ref i), “We have noted that you will be extending the Performance
Security in due course...”. There is no requirement under Contract to renew PS at least 28 days before
its expiry date when it is obvious that the Contractor cannot complete the Works before the expiry date
and the PIC failed to identify the ground of its request in its letter.

There was not a requirement to submit the renewed PS by 18 December 2021 and as such the
Contractor has not failed to renew the PS in accordance with the GCC. PIC is mistaken on this point
and has misinterpreted the requirements. Consequently, the Contractor rejects PIC’s allegations that it
has failed to renew the PS in accordance with the Conditions of Contract and further rejects the assertion
that there has been any breach of Sub-Clause 4.2 of the GCC.

The Contractor has commenced work on extending the PS and reasserts that it has complied with Sub-
Clause 4.2 and emphasizes that there are no concerns regarding successful extension of the PS before
the expiry date. Both the Employer and PIC will be updated on the process of extension of the PS in
due course. Meanwhile the Contractor shall continue to focus on the ongoing negotiations for
fqanatioipef the Works as stated previously.

In response to PIC letter referenced [a] above, UJV would like to respond the following.

As early as in April 2020, UJV reminded PIC via the letter ref.[e] that 22kV cables had been specified and purchased
83 per contract requirements and they were not able to withstand permanent immersion in water. UJV reminds PIC that
22kV cables specifications are compiant with Contract’s technical specification.

To mitigate the delay of Depot drainage compietion, UJV proposed to install temporary pumps via the letter ref. [d] and
[b] provided that trench drainage connections would be completed and operational by end of January 2021 and provided
that “Permanent drainage works from CP05 shall be complete and operational by end of April 2021 at the latest in view
of the rainy season since UJV temporary drainage solution would be suitable for dry season only". These target dates
were confirmed by PIC via the latter ref.[c]. However, to date, trench drainage connections are not operational,
permanent drainage works have not been completed yet and the drainage in Depot trenches is not operational. As a
result, CPO6 does not accept responsibility for any damage caused by water.

DOC received Letter No. 1643/DSDT-DA1 on December 07 2017 of MRB on transplanting
alternative of Dalbergia Tonkinensis Prain in the construction scope of underground stations under
Hanoi Light Metro line 3 Project, Nhon- Hanoi railway station section and permit application on tree
felling, trimming and transplanting, in which, requesting transplantation of 102 trees and felling of 55
trees within land acquisition scope for construction of underground station No, 10 and 12 in Cat Linh,
Cua Nam and Tran Hung Dao ward.

DOC conducted site visit to evaluate existing condition of trees located in construction area of
underground station No. 10 and 12 under Hanoi Light Metro line 3 Project, Nhon- Hanoi railway
station section. Participants include representative of DOC, Urban infrastructure maintenance Board,
Hanoi Greeen Park Co., Ltd, MRB, People Committee of Cat Linh ward (Dong Da district), Cua
Nam, Tran Hung Dao ward (Hoan Kiem district), Hanoi city.
Based on the result of site visit and evaluation of shade-tres quality, DOC herewith reports HPC as
follows:
1. The actual condition of the tree system located within the site area of underground

- Regarding 12 Dalbergia Tonkinensis Prain with D13 from 20 to 42cm and Hvn from 5-
12m to be transplanted is high value tree and shall be preserved. MRB recommends to
transplant and handover to Hoa Binh park for management, protection and taking
care. Checking result indicates that Hoa Binh park is an opened park and far from
residential area, therefore, causing difficulty in management, protection of this
valuable tree.

Delayed Commencement Date and Adjusted Time for Completion.

formal request has not been issued by MRB.

1458/DSDT-DA1 dated 30/10/2017 and letter ref. no. 183/DSDT-DA1 dated 05/02/2018, which highlights that
there has been little progress since October 2017.

HGU is deeply concerned the progress of Contract Amendment which has to be completed within and no later
than 6 months from the date of MoU. We would like to request MRB’s prompt action on this issue.

c. 1870/DSDT-DA1, received 21/10/2021

We acknowledge receipt of your letter ref. [a] and fully reject MRB’s allegation that UJV is in any way responsible for
the fact that CA2 has not been finalized to this date.

We remind that UJV's position has always been that the Contract Amendment for the Elevated Section (CA2) cannot
be signed unless and until the Parties have agreed on the revised Time for Completion of the Elevated Section and
accordingly, the appropriate EoT and cost compensation to be granted by Employer to the Contractor. This position
has been communicated several times and is conform to the spirit of the Heads of Terms dated August 7, 2020 (HoT).
The dates indicated in the HoT are and always were tentative and were to be finalized and agreed between the Parties
via CA2.

UNV refers in particular to its letter ref. [d] which explains in details the history of negotiations of CA2 and the numerous
efforts and attempts from UJV to come to an agreement.
To the contrary, UJV reminds that:

- UJV has sent 29 interim EOT ciaims since March 2018 with no detalled reaponse from MRB / PIC other than
& mere “unsubstantiated” without any explanation, indication or guidance as to what MRB/PIC requires or
allegediy needs to assess UJV's claim.

document no, PIC-MLT-04518-17-V dated 14/12/2017 of Systra Consultant giving comments on
the report on newly planted trees at the ramp and Station S12.

within the area of underground stations under Hanoi Pilot Light Metro Line Project, section Nhon

contractor are requested to submit the dossiers for DOC to grant the tree relocation permit to

Subject: Contract Package No 06: UJV response to MRB comments on payment
procedure for IPC 36 and IPC37
UY Letter Reference No: UJV-MLT.00189.23-E-UJV

UJV acknowledges receipt of MRB's letter ref [a] whereby MRB provided its excuses not to pay for the amount rel
to the Variation of Temporary LV panels certified in IPC 36 as well as the amount related to the Variation of Additi
Training certified in IPC 37.

UJV Is very surprised with this statement from MRB and totally disagrees with MRB’s position. Dealing with the approval
from competent authorities for the increase in cost estimate of any Variation related to CP06 package is none of UJV's
business and is purely the internal work of MRB. This process should have been done before any confirmation from
MRB to allow the Engineer to issue its Instruction to UJV.

Because of this wrong internal MRB procedure, MRB has substantially failed to perform its obligation under the Contract
to pay UJV the amount due under above-mentioned IPC. It has materially and adversely affected the economic balance
of UJV and the ability of UJV to perform the contract.

UJV, once again, requests MRB to pay UJV, without further delay, the full amount of certified IPC as per provisions of
Contract.
UJV reserves its right under the Contract and/or at law.

UJV carried out a site inspection at station 1 on 17 April 2019 in order to assess site readiness for commencement of our
Signalling and Telecom/OCC/SCADA installation works on 15 May 2019 as per approved CP06 Baseline Programme.
(As per site inspection report in attachment, site was found far from ready for UJV access.

As etated in the captioned Interface Management Procedure [a], PIC should notify UJV of the readiness of the site no
later than 28 days before the expected hand-over of the site through HOTSA process for our installation activities. Since
we have not received such notification for station 1 site to date and following our recent site inspection, we expect that
our access to this site for our upcoming Signalling and Telecom/OCC/SCADA installation works will be delayed. While
UJV will keep monitoring CP02 site progress, we would like to remind PIC to Issue HOTSA notification in due time upon
readiness of the site in suitable condition for the start of our upcoming works.

Dear Sirs,
In response to above-captioned letter [b] from PIC, UJV would like to respond the following.

UJV reminds that the aim of a Compliance Matrix Is to ensure and demonstrate the coverage of the Contract
requirements successively at the end of design phase and throughout the Testing & Commissioning period. The
Compilance Matrix indicates cross-references between each and every technical Contractual requirement and the
associated covering document, and provides the compliance status for each requirement captured. The purpose of the
Compliance Matrix is therefore not to link each and every document submitted with the corresponding requirements but
Instead to nk each and every requirement captured with a covering document to ensure that all requirements are
covered. The process implemented by UJV and deacribed in the Requirement Management Pian is compliant with
abovementioned principle and satisfies the need for traceability of requirements coverage.

For Design Phase, UJV has submitted on 01/02/19 (ref [c]), a firet version of the Compliance Matrix in due time before
the end of definitive design phase. An update has been submitted on 05/04/19 via letter [a] and regular updates are
scheduled to be submitted to reach 100% coverage by the end of the Detailed Design Phase.

Subject: CP03—Cost Analysis document of Contract Amendmest
Reply to the MRB letter Ref. No. 1140/DSDT-DA1 dated 28/08/2017

With regard to the MRB’s letter referenced above, the clarification meeting was held on 12/09/17 and
15/09/17 and we have already presented cost analysis documents which were revised according to MRB and
PIC’s comments.

During those two meetings, we explained basis of cost calculation to MRB with detailed substantiations
which was requested us to prove and replied faithfully in terms of MRB’s request for clarifications.

However, we do not agree with your comment that “the document is not followed procedure of variation
request (VR) of signed Contract 1 (Clause &4, 13.3 and 20.1 in GCC, Volume 1)...”. Because the cost
submission for adjusted Time for Completion and delayed Commencement Date is not the variation request
but costs of claim which are prepared and fully complied with Memorandum of Understanding that was
entered into 25/01/17 between MRB and HGU.

In addition, we have looked into Circular 04/2010/TT-BXD issued on 26/05/15 by Ministry of Construction.
However, we would like to highlight that the Circular is mostly related with calculation for revision of direct
costs and therefore, this Circular is not applied for our costs claim. In case MRB should pursue us to apply
for the Circular at our submission, we would like to request further clarification from MRB in respect of
providing specific reference in the circular where MRB has relied upon pertaining to Contractor's obligation
or entitlement on cost and profit.

Subject: CP00—Time-Based Contract Addendum No.9.1— Mobilization Plan and Cost Estimates
Reference:
[a] MRB letter 685/DSDT-DA1 dated 26/04/2023
[b] PIC fetter PIC-MLT-01639-23 dated 26/04/2023
[c) PIC letter PIC-MLT-01900-23 dated 05/05/2023

We acknowledge receipt of your letter [a] wherein you gave your comments on the Mobilization Plan
and Cost Estimates of PIC Time-Based Contract No.9.1. In response to your letter above, we would
like to give further explanation and comments as follows:

We confirm that our latest submission including mobilization plan and justifications of resources was
already optimized several times taking into consideration of MRB’s comments. This tentative
mobilization plan cannot be optimized more except if MRB planned to take the responsibility to
manage directly some “engineer” tasks.

As reminder, PIC emphasize again that for all new mobilizations, the CV of personnel will be
submitted to MR following project progress for approval before mobilization.

The contractual local rates are no more valid and shall be one of the topics to be negotiated between
PIC and MRB for the contract extension as stated in our letter [¢] on Time-Based contract expiration.

As per the signed Time-Based Contract in 2007, the rates and the price revision applied Syntec index
which cannot reflect the Vietnamese inflation conditions for the coming past 16 years for local rates
and longer duration until project completion date. Consequently, Systra has been suffering financial
loss on a lot of local positions in order to ensure the services quality required by MRB to PIC’s local
staffs in terms of diploma and certification.

no confirmation of the final power balance for the Depot has been received by UJV. The original baseline programme
date for receipt of this final data was 16 May 2018.

progress of Auxillary Transformers scope of Works and potentially impact on the project as a whole, and generate
additional costs for which UJV will seek compensation.

the PCC and GCC for all delays and potential costs associated with the failure to confirm on time the depot power load
In order to size depot transformers and diesel generators accordingly.

Dear Sirs,
In response to PIC letter referenced [a] above, UJV would like to respond the following.

With regards to PIC statement that “We are of the opinion that the content of your fetter [a] is insufficient to support
the validity of your claim nor aliowed us to review the impact of the site conditions to your actual works progress”,
UJV would like to highlight that our notification was described in letter ref.[b] in full compliance with GCC 20.1:
- Firstly, the notice of delayed site access from CP05 (Depot Workshop & access fully completed & handed over)
to CP06 for Depot Equipment activities was served to MRB/PIC in a timely manner on 17/07/2019 via the letter
ref. [e]. As a requirement of coordination via interface and construction meetings, UJV updated CP06 B
activities based on assumptions of revised access dates and prerequisites which must be completed by CP05
prior to HOTSA via the letter ref.[c]. However, on 1 March 2021, the CPO5 revised operational target required
in UJV letter [c] related to access of building 6 for installation of high-pressure washing machine, has not been
achieved. Therefore, the letter ref. [b] was served to notify and record the delayed milestone of CPO6. It is
obvious that access from CP05 (Depot Workshop & access fully completed & handed over) to CP06 for Depot
Equipment activities has been delayed continuously.
- With regards to PIC question about the impact of site condition with respect to works progress, it is obvious
that an access which is not received from CP05 prevents CPO6 activity to start, in the case of this letter the
installation of high-pressure washing machine in building 6.

Contractor has completely denied the Employer's efforts effort in settling land acquisition difficulties
to grant the site access as well as in giving favourable conditions to accelerate the procedures and
being flexible in payment of invoices to the Contractor. Further to Letter ref. no. 89/DSDT-DA| dated
20/01/2021, MRB would like to clarify HGU’s claims as follows:

- Based on the Bidding documents of the Employer, bid documents, Method statements and Traffic
management plans submitted by HGU at the letter ref. HGU-IMP-PPG-ZPO-L]0-00002-EV-3A, all
indicating that except for Ramp and S9 to be constructed on the entire area of the main structures, the
remaining sites will be constructed in phases using part of the site, the remaining site will be used for
traffic diversion following a proper traffic management plan approved by DOT.

In spite of falling behind the tentative schedule, up to now, MRB has handed over the Site to
the Contractor to carry out the construction of almost main work items of CP03. As for the statement
of the Contractor that the site has not been handed over for several work items, MRB would like to

The Jet Grouting Plug proposed by HGU, for Station 12, is a new construction technology in Vietnam
and currently there is neither a construction norm nor any other legal document issued by competent
authorities for pricing of such kind of works. Due to the aforesaid justification and In order to allow the
normal approval flow for the Variation Request (VR), PIC has no objection to HGU’s proposal of creating
a new construction norm to reflect the right methodology and reasonable unit price.

The new construction norm and new unit price for Jet Grouting item should be established by a
specialized governmental agency (such as ICE) who has enough experience and authority to stablish
new norms for MRB/HPC/MOC approval.

UJV refers to its letter ref [a] and MRB's letter ref [b] whereby both parties agreed to select option 3 of the Dispute
Board Agreement (/.e., the Parties revert to General Conditions of Dispute Board Agreement as attached in Appendix
of the Contract).

Based on this agreement and the comments from MRB, the DB submitted its final draft of DBA on 01 March 2023.
However, this draft, as stated in UJV's email dated 17 March 2023, does not take into account the payment mechanism
which was agreed by UJV and MRB under Particulars Conditions of the original Contract.

In the light of respecting the signed Contract as confirmed by MRB in its email dated 6 October 2022, and to address
the impartiality Issue raised by the DB members , UJV would like to propose a payment mechanism in which each party
shall pay half of each of the Member's invoices after receiving each invoice.

On this basis, to proceed with signature of DBA, UJV would like to request MRB to give it final position on this matter
and Indicate whether it agrees with the above payment mechanism.
UJV expects to receive MRB's response no later than 14 April 2023.

Subject: Contract Package No 06: UJV response to MRB comments on payment
procedure for IPC 36 and IPC37
UY Letter Reference No: UJV-MLT.00189.23-E-UJV

UJV acknowledges receipt of MRB's letter ref [a] whereby MRB provided its excuses not to pay for the amount rel
to the Variation of Temporary LV panels certified in IPC 36 as well as the amount related to the Variation of Additi
Training certified in IPC 37.

UJV Is very surprised with this statement from MRB and totally disagrees with MRB’s position. Dealing with the approval
from competent authorities for the increase in cost estimate of any Variation related to CP06 package is none of UJV's
business and is purely the internal work of MRB. This process should have been done before any confirmation from
MRB to allow the Engineer to issue its Instruction to UJV.

Because of this wrong internal MRB procedure, MRB has substantially failed to perform its obligation under the Contract
to pay UJV the amount due under above-mentioned IPC. It has materially and adversely affected the economic balance
of UJV and the ability of UJV to perform the contract.

UJV, once again, requests MRB to pay UJV, without further delay, the full amount of certified IPC as per provisions of
Contract.
UJV reserves its right under the Contract and/or at law.

Reference to Letter No/ Date: a. PIC-MILT-01811-22-E, received 24/06/2022
b. PIC-MLT-02024-22-, received 14/07/2022

UJV refers to the letter ref [a] whereby the Engineer, in accordance with Sub-Clause 3.6 [Deferminations] of the General
Conditions of Contract, determined additional payment in reference to the UJV's claim for extension of Time for
Completion of Elevated Section.

Following this determination, UJV submitted its IPC#34 showing In detail the amounts to which UJV was entitled for.
However, the Engineer issued the IPCiK34 certificate in the ref [b] in which it was deducted an amount corresponding
to repayment of advance payment clause.

UJV is of the opinion that, as it is not defined in the Contract, the Sub-clause 14.2a [Repayment amortization of Advanoe
Payment] should not be applied to the IPC directly connected to the Contractor's claim for which the Engineer has
already given its determination. Indeed, this clause should only be applied to the normal application for interim payment
certificates including the payment for Variations as per Sub-Clause 14.3 [Application for interim Payment Certificates).

UJV, therefore, disagrees with the Engineer's deduction of Advance Payment associated with the IPC’s amount related
to the amount determined by the Engineer's in the ref [a].
UJV trusts the above clarifies the matter.

Employer/Engineer once again, denied the UJV's reasonable request in referenced letter [b] and [c] for issuance of a
Taking Over Certificate under Sub-Clause 10.3 [interference with Tests on Completion] of the General Conditions of
Contract (GCC). UJV would like to respond as follows:

UJV reminds that under the Contract, after the successful completion of Test Run (so-called phase 7a of the Tests on
Completion), the Contractor's works are limited to supporting the Employer to carry out the Trial Run (phase 8 of the
Tests on Completion).

There is no doubt that the Contractor has been prevented for more than 14 days from providing its support to the
Employer to carry out the Trial Run, for a cause for which the Employer is responsible. Therefore, in strict accordance
with Sub-Clause 10.3 [/nferferance with Tests on Completion), of GCC, UJV maintains and reiterates its position as
stated in its above referenced letter (c] and [d] and once again, requests that the Engineer issue the TOC for the Elevated
Section with effective date no later than 15 February 2023.

Subject: CP03—Cost Analysis document of Contract Amendmest
Reply to the MRB letter Ref. No. 1140/DSDT-DA1 dated 28/08/2017

With regard to the MRB’s letter referenced above, the clarification meeting was held on 12/09/17 and
15/09/17 and we have already presented cost analysis documents which were revised according to MRB and
PIC’s comments.

During those two meetings, we explained basis of cost calculation to MRB with detailed substantiations
which was requested us to prove and replied faithfully in terms of MRB’s request for clarifications.

However, we do not agree with your comment that “the document is not followed procedure of variation
request (VR) of signed Contract 1 (Clause &4, 13.3 and 20.1 in GCC, Volume 1)...”. Because the cost
submission for adjusted Time for Completion and delayed Commencement Date is not the variation request
but costs of claim which are prepared and fully complied with Memorandum of Understanding that was
entered into 25/01/17 between MRB and HGU.

In addition, we have looked into Circular 04/2010/TT-BXD issued on 26/05/15 by Ministry of Construction.
However, we would like to highlight that the Circular is mostly related with calculation for revision of direct
costs and therefore, this Circular is not applied for our costs claim. In case MRB should pursue us to apply
for the Circular at our submission, we would like to request further clarification from MRB in respect of
providing specific reference in the circular where MRB has relied upon pertaining to Contractor's obligation
or entitlement on cost and profit.

UJV hereby responds to the Engineer's letter above-captioned letter [a]. UJV totally disagrees with the arguments put
forward by the Engineer and rejects the same for the following reason.

As stated by the Engineer, the prerequisite for this payment milestone as noted in IPS (Interim Payment Schedule) is
“acknowledge receipt of 3D design file, issued by Contractor and approved by the Engineer/Employer”. The approval
relates to the Acknowledge receipt and not the design file itself as the Approval of the Design file is the purpose of a
separate payment milestone 1-T3 “Approval of all 3D design”. UJV has sent all 3D design files through MTS 30067, 30091,
30082 and 30095 respectively on 27/02/19, 05/03/19, 06/03/19 and 06/03/19. Two Acknowledge receipts signed by the
Engineer are dated respectively 28/02/19 and 07/03/19, whereas the other two are dated 12/03/19 due to several requests
from the Engineer to resend the CD. The MaA was rejected on 17/04/19 (Le 41 days after the submission of the MoA)
whereas all 3D design files had been submitted by 06/09/19 and all acknowledge receipts signed by 12/03/19 (see
Attachment #1). The Contractor was fully entitled to claim for the payment of this milestone in March 2019.

In response to PIC letter referenced [a] above, UJV would like to respond the following.

On 2 June 2021, UJV received PIC’s instruction to access Depot building No.7 via the letter ref. [f], However, as
feminded several times and stated in the letter ref.[g], sufficient advance notice (two months) is required to make
necessary arrangements for the mission of Supplier in COVID context.

Furthermore, pending issues regarding the presence of water in the anchor reservation, missing sum pump as stated
in the letter ref.[c] have not been clarified by PIC.

Based on the above, UJV rejects PIC’s statement that “You were late in mobilizing experts for the installation of pit
wheel lathe machine in Building 7 of Depot, and therefore you are not entitled fo any alleged extension of time and/or
additional payment

With regards to the site coordination, UJV confirms that technical coordination has been made between CP6 & CP05
to reduce anchor depth of 350mm for certain locations. CP05 requested to start acting no more than 1 week before the
DEQ installation start date, however CPO5 only completed anchor reservation on 9 November 2021, hence the further
delay and immobilization as mentioned in letter [b]. UJV proactively reiterated this issue to PIC/CPOS vie the letters
ref.{c}, [d] & [e}.
Thus, UJV maintains its position as stated in the letter ref.[b] regarding the accessibility of Depot building 7.

Part B) and a limited amount of clarifications. We are of the view that this draft does not cover the intention of the
Parties a3 expressed in the Heads of Terms (HOT) to finalize and agree to all necessary amendments (contractual,
financial and operational) for the operation of the line in two phases.

We summarize in the following UJV's comments on the draft issued by MRB.
|. MRB CA2 Draft - Provisions Agreed in Principle

- Defect Notification Period (DNP) for Elevated Section and for Underground Section: 24 months respectively
- Definition of Sections:
Elevated Section: Works for the viaduct, eight elevated stations and the Depot.
Underground Section: Works for the tunnels, emergency shaft, crossover & garage, the ramp and four
underground stations and includes the additional activities as per Annex 6 of the HOT such as but not limited
to the demonstration of the Full Line performance. UJV reminds that the parties will have to mutually agree on
the compensation of Contractor for the additional activities of the Underground section (such as but not limited
to demonstration of full ine performance) in accordance with the HOT.

In response to letter referenced above [a], UJV would like to respond the following.

1. UJV hereby corrects the typing mistake made in letter [a] when referring to PCC 3.1 [d] instead of GCC 3.1 [d]. This |
is to remind the Engineer's duty to respond to a Contractor's request within 28 days of receipt. '

i
2. The fact that the Engineer has questioned in above referenced letter UJV's capability to understand that the 27MVA 1
power capacity was only for elevated section clearly demonstrates that the Engineer has underestimated or
misunderstood the concern of all Parties in relation with the connection to EVN network. The issue was precisely on
the way EVN would extend the power capacity from 27MVA to a final 37MVA, without jeopardizing the whole
medium voltage architecture. Such outcome woukd have had a dramatic impact on the elevated 22kV backbone and
equipment ratings with tremendous consequences for the Employer and the Project organization, as discussed
during the various meetings held on the subject since April 2018. In such circumstances, It was clearly the
responsibility of UJV to warn on the potential risk and ask for direction in order to mitigate the risks for the Employer.

UJV refers to above-captioned letter [a] from PIC whereby PIC considers that the Interim Claim #1 from UJV under ref \\|

[b] Is unfounded allegedly under the contract terms. PIC's argument is that no Application of Interim Payment Certificate
has been submitted by the Contractor under GCC 14.3 or IPC issued by the Engineer as per 14.6 for which the
Contractor can claim the payment under GCC 14.7 and 14.8.
UJV totally disagrees with the Engineer's position and rejects the same for the following reason.

UJV considers to be fully entitied to additional payment under Clause 20.1 of the Conditions of Contract and has served
related notices to the Engineer accordingly. The entitiement of the Contractor derives from the fact that the Engineer has
falled to comply with its contractual obligation under Sub-Clause 1.3 of the Conditions of Contract by unreasonably and
unjustifiably delaying the approval of the supporting documents underlying UJV Application for Payment Certificate, as
detailed in the Claim file in ref. [b]. As a consequence of the failure of the Engineer to comply with its obligation, UJV has
been prevented from exercising its fundamental contractual right of applying for Interim Payment Certificates by
submitting a Statement with supporting documents, in accordance with Clause 14.3 of the Conditions of Contract, and
getting paid for the works done, in accordance with Clause 14.7 of the Conditions of Contract. The direct prejudice
suffered by UJV as a result of the unreasonable delay in the approval of supporting documents by the Engineer is
payment delay and the quantification of the prejudice is based on the calculation method stipulated in Clause 14.8 of the

agreement between Alstom and Colas Rail for the share of works of sub-systems 6B and 6F, equipment and

amount In the coming days. According to Section IV.3(a) of the Minutes of Contract Negotiation dated 21

the money related to the IPA N°47 and N°48 was certified by the Engineer in letters (d) and (e), the
Employer is responsible for refunding the CIT of the Contractor relating to the above money.

on due time. Financial interests for late payment as defined in the Contract, refer to clause 14.8 of the

UJV acknowledges receipt of the MRB’s letter ref [a] whereby UJV was requested to supplement the basis and grounds
for determining the cost items of the additional Trainings in accordance with reality. In particular, MRB stated that the
tate of 60 euro/person/day Is inappropriate and insufficient for evaluation. UJV disagrees with this statement and would
like to respond as follows:

1. UJV has proactively considered all possible deductible amounts in the Variation Proposal (i.e., training
expenses, production training materials or contract document training).

2. As already explained in UJV's letter ref [b), in the additional training Variation Proposal, the amount of additional
dally expenses for trainees is used to pay for not only lunch but for other costs like the rental fee of classroom,
car rental, additional facilities/amenities serving the classroom. Indeed, as per contractual provisions, facilities
such as classrooms, overhead projectors, VCRs and video monitors should be made available for imparting
training in Depot free of cost to UJV. Therefore, these costs were not Included in the UJV's reply to the request
for price clarification — appendix 3 attached to document no. HANOO-0-SYS-M100-04003 which only covers flight
tickets, meals, training tools and hotel. However, UJV had to pay practically all these costs.

4. MRB agreed, in the signed Contract, with UJV's clarification for 60 euro daily expense for training on-shore for
one person per day. It is not reasonable and does not make any sense to challenge again what has been agreed
and signed between the MRB and UJV. Furthermore, this unit/price was made and agreed more than 6 years

Dear Sirs,
In response to above referenced letter {a], UJV would like to reply the following.

In the first place, UJV disagrees with PIC's statement that “Your allegation that the General Works Programme (GWP)
is baseless and without proper justification”. UJV adequately explained in details and substantiated with clear examples
why the General Works Programme is unrealistic via the letters ref. [b), [c] and [d]. UJV's position In this regard remains
unchanged.

With regards to coordination with other designated contractors, UJV has proactively lead preparation and coordination
works with CP02, CP07, EVN, MRB and the Engineer as already mentioned and substantiated in our letter ref. [b).
Moreover, since power on dates have been delayed by many events which are beyond UJV's control as listed in our
letter ref. [b] and UJV did not record any impact on other Contractors due to Power On to date, UJV also fully disagrees
with PIC’s statement that “Nevertheless, you were late in coordinating with other Designated Contractors, as recorded
in our letter [d] & [e] and had caused impact to other Designated Contractors and subsequently to the progress of the
Project”.

Based on the above, UJV still rejects the Notice of Employer's Claim ref. ERC/CP06/05-20/025 for a lack of preparation
for energization.
